Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: A Cloud-assisted Framework for Improving Pedestrian Safety in Urban Communities using Crowd-sourced Mobile and Wearable Device Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Pedestrian safety continues to be a significant concern in urban communities. Several recent reports indicate that injuries and fatalities in pedestrian-related accidents are steadily rising and that pedestrian distraction is one of the leading causes in such accidents. Existing systems and techniques for improving pedestrian safety, which primarily operate on users' smartphones and mobile devices in a stand-alone fashion, have several design drawbacks and performance and usability concerns that have precluded their successful adoption and usage. The goal of this project is to improve pedestrian safety by designing accurate, efficient and usable tools and techniques, which can be easily adopted by urban users.

In order to accomplish this goal, this project plans to pursue a focused research agenda involving novel technologies and several exploratory and untested ideas. As part of the proposed pedestrian safety framework, accurate and energy-efficient on-device distraction detection techniques will be developed by employing multi-sensor and heterogeneous data available from upcoming mobile and wearable devices. In this direction, supervised and semi-supervised learning will be used to design efficient activity classification and distraction prediction techniques which will be empirically evaluated using proof-of-concept implementations. Unlike existing stand-alone approaches, the proposed framework employs a connected-community approach to accurately capture the impact of both a pedestrian's own actions, as well as the actions of others, on his/her safety. This involves the design and implementation of a privacy-preserving and cloud-assisted data-analytics engine to capture, analyze and notify pedestrians of impending hazardous situations from the crowd-sourced distraction data obtained from participating users. Finally, a comprehensive performance and usability evaluation will be conducted by deploying a large-scale testbed involving participants from Wichita State University's (WSU) campus community. The project outcomes, including the planned testbed, will have a significant impact on improving pedestrian safety within the WSU campus community. If successful, similar trials at an urban or city-wide scale can also be envisioned. In addition to improving pedestrian safety, this project will educate users and participants on the impact of technology on pedestrian safety and its role in improving the same. Project outcomes and results will be disseminated by means of peer-reviewed publications, white papers and open-source applications. Applications and anonymous data collected from the planned testbed will be appropriately disseminated to facilitate additional research and advances in the area of pedestrian safety technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project's goal was to improve pedestrian safety in our urban communities by developing accurate, responsive and usable pedestrian safety tools and techniques by combining sensor data and context available from a heterogeneous set of mobile and wearable devices (and sensors) in possession of the user and leveraging relevant community- or crowd-sourced data and analytics. The project accomplished the following specific objectives:

(i) New pedestrian distraction detection techniques: Distraction is generally a precursor to pedestrian accidents, and mitigating such hazards requires pedestrian safety applications that are effective in detecting them quickly. Detecting pedestrian distraction is possible with the availability of sophisticated mobile and wearable devices that are equipped with high-precision on-board sensors capable of capturing fine-grained user movements and context. However, the key technical challenge is achieving accurate recognition of distractions in real-time, given the memory, computation and communication limitations of these devices. Traditional machine learning based complex activity recognition techniques that employ multi-source data can be used for the distraction detection task. Despite being able to achieve very high detection accuracy, most of these current approaches are either resource intensive and unsuitable for implementation on mainstream mobile devices, or computationally slow and not useful for real-time pedestrian safety applications, or require specialized hardware and less likely to be adopted by most users. To design a generic pedestrian distraction detection approach that can operate on commercial mobile and wearable devices and achieve a favorable balance between accuracy, responsiveness and usability, we designed a novel activity recognition technique, called Dominant Frequency-based Activity Matching (DFAM). By means of a comprehensive comparative evaluation using distraction data collected from human subject pedestrians in realistic settings, we showed that DFAM's recognition accuracy is comparable to traditional learning-based approaches in the literature. Moreover, DFAM is computational and power efficient compared to these approaches and has a faster detection speed. 


(ii) Mobile and wearable device based notification modalities: Notification mechanisms to alert distracted pedestrians or drivers is a critical component of any pedestrian safety application, however its design is non-trivial because these notifications can easily become a source of distraction themselves. We studied if tactile warnings from different types of wearable devices are effective in alerting distracted drivers. We conducted experiments where participants wore a smart watch on the wrist, smart ring on the finger, and smart glasses on the head temple area while performing a simulated car-following task. They all finished the driving task under four conditions: without alerts, alerts at finger, wrist and temple area when the lead vehicle braked intermittently. Our results showed that alerts at the finger and wrist produced shorter braking response time than no alert condition while alerting the temple area did not produce significant benefit in response time over no alert condition. Participants also preferred alerts at the finger and wrist than the temple. Our plan going ahead is to extend this study for alerting distracted pedestrians.


(iii) Pedestrian safety testbed: We designed and deployed a large-scale pedestrian safety testbed on the University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA) campus, comprising of wearable/mobile devices and participants who crowd source on-board sensor and safety-related feedback data by means of these devices, with the goal of employing this testbed for studying the proposed pedestrian distraction detection and notification frameworks and other relevant pedestrian safety issues/challenges. As the first use-case of this testbed, we studied the pedestrian safety issues resulting from micro-mobility vehicle services such as e-scooters. We also plan to use this testbed to evaluate the pedestrian distraction detection and notification approaches proposed earlier.


Broader Impacts:Traditionally, women are underrepresented in STEM and Computer Science area. By giving appropriate research and graduate education opportunities to a well-qualified female student, Ms. Nisha Vinayaga-Sureshkanth, this project contributed towards increasing the number and representation of women in these areas of national importance. The project's research outcomes advanced the current state-of-the-art in the area of pedestrian distraction detection algorithms, and concurrent activity recognition in general, and it is our hope that they are adopted by future pedestrian safety applications. The project's outcomes have been disseminated to the research and industry communities by means of refereed publications and research reports. Anonymized experimental datasets and prototype source codes will also be available to interested researchers/developers upon request. The pedestrian safety testbed developed in this project will provide the UTSA campus community the hardware/software infrastructure required to conduct future data collection experiments and studies on improving the state of pedestrian safety on campus. This testbed will also be made accessible to neighboring community colleges and state university campuses so that they can employ it to study similar pedestrian safety issues on their campuses.
